The movie resolution is 1920x800 and not 1920x1080, because this movie was filmed with a 2.35 aspect ratio, so you are seeing it in the way it was designed to be viewed. Only movies filmed with 1.77 aspect ratios will use 1920x1080 resolution. You can look up the technical specs on imdb to find out the original aspect ratio.

@Beowulf6666 
because the movie has been originally shot using an aspect ratio of 2.39:1, the ripper has cropped the image, removing the black bars located on the top and bottom (there are numerous benefits to this and no detriments that I am aware of). 
As a result of this process, the resolution is inevitably changed to 1920x800. 
http://www.blu-ray.com/movies/John-Carter-3D-Blu-ray/34573/

@asimsh7
wrong, see above. and if you'd be silly enough to maintain that only a rip that contains the black bars is 'true', then good luck finding one cause i don't think i have ever seen a rip where they leave them in. 
as far as the quality is concerned, it is difficult to say with 3D screens, and as i have not downloaded this rip, i cannot comment. 

further reading:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cropping_(image)
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Display_resolution
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aspect_ratio_(image) 

helpful information related to blu-ray rips in the IMAX format (eg Transformers 2): 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IMAX
Its 1920x800 instead 1080 because most movies aren't shot in 16:9, they're shot in 2.35:1, wider than wide screen so to speak. Thus 1920/2.35=817 ish pixels

@oki111
hard to say but it sounds to me like you have your TVs 3D function set to stack the 3D images vertically, instead of horizontally (ie. side-by-side or 'SBS'). i believe trying to watch an H-SBS movie with your display set to vertical stacking would produce an effect similar to what you describe.
